canonical_explanation.text: Food is essential for all living organisms and comes from plants (crops) and animals (livestock, fish, poultry). Crops are classified as kharif (sown in rainy season, e.g., paddy, maize, soybean) and rabi (sown in winter, e.g., wheat, gram, mustard). Crop improvement aims for higher yield, disease resistance, and quality through hybridisation (cross-breeding), introduction of desired genes, and genetic modification. Crop production management involves nutrient management (manures and fertilizers), irrigation, and cropping patterns (mixed cropping, intercropping, crop rotation). Manures are organic and improve soil structure, while fertilizers are chemical and provide specific nutrients (NPK). Crop protection involves controlling weeds, insect pests, and diseases using pesticides, biological control, and good agricultural practices. Proper storage prevents losses from biotic (insects, rodents) and abiotic (moisture, temperature) factors. Animal husbandry includes cattle farming (milch and draught breeds), poultry farming (broilers and layers), fish production (marine and inland fisheries), and bee keeping (apiculture) for honey and wax.
rules: Kharif crops: sown in rainy season (June-September). Examples: paddy, maize, soybean, groundnut.
Rabi crops: sown in winter (October-March). Examples: wheat, gram, peas, mustard, linseed.
Crop variety improvement aims for higher yield, disease resistance, and better quality.
Hybridisation: crossing genetically different plants for desired characters.
Manures are organic (compost, vermicompost, green manure) and improve soil structure.
Fertilizers are chemical (NPK) and provide specific nutrients for rapid growth.
Mixed cropping: growing two crops simultaneously on the same field.
Intercropping: growing two crops in alternate rows on the same field.
Crop rotation: growing different crops in succession on the same field.
Cattle: milch breeds (for milk) and draught breeds (for farm work).
Poultry: broilers (for meat) and layers (for eggs).
Fish production: capture fishery (catching from natural sources) and culture fishery (farming fish).
Bee keeping (apiculture): Apis cerana indica (Indian bee) and Apis mellifera (Italian bee).

questions.question_text: Kharif crops are grown during which season?
questions.explanation_correct: Kharif crops are sown at the beginning of the rainy season (June-July) and harvested at the end of the monsoon (September-October). They require a lot of water and warm conditions. Examples include paddy, maize, soybean, and groundnut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Winter crops are called rabi crops. There is no specific category for summer-only or year-round crops in this context. Kharif crops specifically grow during the monsoon/rainy season.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a rabi crop?
questions.explanation_correct: Wheat is a rabi crop, sown in winter (October-November) and harvested in spring (March-April). Other rabi crops include gram, peas, mustard, and linseed. They grow in the cool, dry season.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paddy, maize, and soybean are all kharif crops grown during the rainy season. Wheat is specifically a rabi (winter) crop.

questions.question_text: The crossing of genetically different plants to combine desirable traits is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Hybridisation is the crossing of two genetically different plants (or varieties) to produce offspring that combine the desirable traits of both parents. It can be intervarietal (between two varieties), interspecific (between two species), or intergeneric (between two genera).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Grafting is joining parts of two plants. Cloning produces genetically identical copies. Budding is a form of asexual reproduction. Hybridisation specifically involves cross-breeding for desired traits.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a desired trait in crop improvement?
questions.explanation_correct: Longer maturation time is NOT a desired trait — farmers prefer crops with shorter maturation periods so they can grow more crop cycles in a year. Desired traits include higher yield, disease resistance, quality improvement, wider adaptability, and shorter maturation time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher yield, disease resistance, and wider adaptability are all desired traits. Shorter (not longer) maturation time is desired to allow multiple cropping seasons.

questions.question_text: The three major nutrients required by plants are:
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) are the three major macronutrients required by plants in large quantities. They are essential for plant growth, flowering, and fruiting. This is why fertilizers are often labeled with NPK values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron, zinc, and copper are micronutrients needed in small amounts. Calcium, magnesium, and sulphur are secondary macronutrients. Boron, manganese, and molybdenum are micronutrients. NPK are the primary macronutrients.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an organic method of improving soil fertility?
questions.explanation_correct: Compost and vermicompost are organic manures made from decomposed plant and animal waste. They improve soil structure, water-holding capacity, and provide nutrients gradually. They are organic methods that do not use synthetic chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Urea, DAP, and ammonium nitrate are all chemical fertilizers, not organic methods. Compost (from decomposed waste) and vermicompost (made using earthworms) are organic soil amendments.

questions.question_text: The key difference between manure and fertilizer is:

options.text: Manure is chemical; fertilizer is organic
Manure is organic and improves soil structure; fertilizer is chemical and provides specific nutrients
Fertilizer improves soil structure; manure provides specific nutrients

questions.explanation_correct: Manure is organic, prepared from animal and plant waste through decomposition. It improves soil structure, water-holding capacity, and adds humus. Fertilizer is manufactured chemically and provides specific nutrients (N, P, K) quickly but does not improve soil structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and D reverse the characteristics. They are not the same — manure is organic and improves soil health, while fertilizers are chemical and supply specific nutrients rapidly.

questions.question_text: Growing two or more crops simultaneously on the same field in a definite pattern is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Intercropping involves growing two or more crops simultaneously on the same field in a definite row pattern (e.g., soybean + maize in alternate rows). This ensures that even if one crop fails, the other survives, reducing risk and maximizing use of nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixed cropping grows two crops together without a specific pattern. Crop rotation grows different crops in succession. Monoculture grows only one crop. Intercropping specifically uses a definite row pattern.

questions.question_text: Growing different crops on the same field in successive seasons is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Crop rotation is the practice of growing different crops in succession on the same field in different seasons. For example, growing a cereal (wheat) followed by a legume (gram). This maintains soil fertility and reduces pest and disease buildup.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixed cropping and intercropping involve growing crops simultaneously. Shifting cultivation involves moving to new land. Crop rotation specifically involves growing different crops one after another in successive seasons.

questions.question_text: Vermicompost is prepared using:
questions.explanation_correct: Vermicompost is prepared by using earthworms to decompose organic waste such as plant remains, kitchen waste, and animal dung. The earthworms eat the organic matter and excrete nutrient-rich castings (worm excreta) that form excellent manure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vermicompost is not made chemically, by burning, or by industrial processing. It is an organic process using earthworms. The prefix 'vermi' means worm.

questions.question_text: Cattle used for farm labour such as ploughing and carting are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Draught animals are cattle breeds used for farm labour such as ploughing, irrigation, and carting. They are sturdy and strong. Milch animals are those raised primarily for milk production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milch animals are raised for milk. Broilers and layers are poultry terms (meat and eggs respectively). Draught animals specifically do farm work.

questions.question_text: In poultry farming, hens raised primarily for egg production are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Layers are poultry hens raised specifically for egg production. They start laying eggs at about 20 weeks of age. Broilers are poultry birds raised for meat. The nutritional and housing requirements of layers and broilers are different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Broilers are raised for meat, not eggs. Milch and draught are cattle categories. Layers specifically refers to egg-producing hens in poultry farming.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an exotic breed of cattle known for high milk production?
questions.explanation_correct: Jersey is an exotic (foreign) cattle breed known for its high milk yield. Other exotic breeds include Holstein-Friesian and Brown Swiss. Cross-breeding exotic breeds with Indian breeds (like Sahiwal, Red Sindhi, Gir) produces animals with high milk yield and disease resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red Sindhi, Sahiwal, and Gir are all Indian (indigenous) breeds. Jersey is an exotic breed from the Jersey Island known for excellent milk production.

questions.question_text: Broilers and layers differ mainly in their:

options.text: Purpose — broilers for meat, layers for eggs
Origin — they come from different countries

questions.explanation_correct: The main difference between broilers and layers is their purpose. Broilers are raised for meat production — they grow quickly and are slaughtered young. Layers are raised for egg production — they are maintained for their egg-laying capacity over a longer period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The difference is not about colour, size, or origin. It is fundamentally about purpose: broilers are for meat and layers are for eggs. Their feed, housing, and management also differ accordingly.

questions.question_text: Aquaculture refers to:

options.text: Farming of fish and other aquatic organisms

questions.explanation_correct: Aquaculture (or culture fishery) refers to the farming of fish, shellfish, and other aquatic organisms in controlled environments such as ponds, tanks, and enclosures. It involves breeding, rearing, and harvesting aquatic species for food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing crops with water is hydroponics. Purifying water is water treatment. Storing water is water management. Aquaculture specifically means farming aquatic organisms.

questions.question_text: Bee keeping (apiculture) is done primarily for the production of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bee keeping (apiculture) is practiced primarily for the production of honey and beeswax. Bees also help in pollination of crops, increasing crop yield. The most commonly reared species are Apis cerana indica (Indian bee) and Apis mellifera (Italian bee).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silk comes from sericulture (silkworm rearing). Wool comes from sheep. Leather comes from cattle hides. Bee keeping specifically produces honey and beeswax.

questions.question_text: The two types of fish production are:
questions.explanation_correct: Fish production involves two methods: capture fishery (catching fish from natural water bodies like oceans, rivers, and lakes) and culture fishery (farming fish in controlled environments like ponds and tanks). Culture fishery is also called aquaculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While marine and river describe locations, the correct classification of production methods is capture (from natural sources) and culture (farmed in controlled environments).

questions.question_text: Composite fish culture involves:

options.text: Growing only one species of fish in a pond
Growing five or six different species of fish together in a single pond
Growing fish only in the ocean

questions.explanation_correct: Composite fish culture (polyculture) involves growing five or six different species of fish together in a single pond. Different species feed at different levels — surface feeders, middle feeders, and bottom feeders — maximizing use of all food resources in the pond without competition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing one species is monoculture. Composite culture specifically means multiple species in one pond. Ocean fish farming and unfed fish are not composite culture.

questions.question_text: Weeds in crop fields are harmful because they:

options.text: Compete with crops for water, nutrients, space, and light

questions.explanation_correct: Weeds are unwanted plants that grow along with crops and compete with them for essential resources like water, nutrients, space, and light. This competition reduces crop yield and quality. Weed control is therefore important in crop management.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weeds do not add nutrients or help crops grow. While some weeds may prevent erosion, their primary effect is harmful — they steal resources from crops, reducing productivity.

questions.question_text: Proper storage of grains is important to prevent losses from:

options.text: Insects, rodents, fungi, moisture, and bacteria

questions.explanation_correct: Stored grains can be damaged by biotic factors (insects, rodents, fungi, mites, bacteria) and abiotic factors (inappropriate moisture content, temperature, and humidity). Proper storage with fumigation, moisture control, and pest management prevents significant food losses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Losses are not only from sunlight or rainfall. Soil erosion does not affect stored grains. The main threats to stored grains are pests (insects, rodents), microorganisms (fungi, bacteria), and environmental conditions (moisture, temperature).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a method of weed control?

options.text: Manual removal (weeding) and use of herbicides

questions.explanation_correct: Weed control methods include manual removal (pulling weeds by hand or using tools), use of herbicides (chemical weed killers like 2,4-D), and cultural methods like proper seed bed preparation and timely sowing to give crops a competitive advantage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding more fertilizer may actually help weeds grow. Planting more seeds does not eliminate weeds. Reducing irrigation would harm crops too. Manual weeding and herbicides are direct weed control methods.

questions.question_text: Green manure is prepared by:

options.text: Growing and then ploughing under green plants (like sun hemp or guar) into the soil
Adding green-coloured chemicals to the field
Burning green leaves in the field

questions.explanation_correct: Green manure is prepared by growing certain plants (like sun hemp, guar, or dhaincha) in the field and then ploughing them into the soil before they mature. These plants decompose and enrich the soil with nitrogen and other nutrients, improving fertility naturally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green manure has nothing to do with paint, chemicals, or burning. It is specifically the practice of growing and incorporating green plants into the soil to add organic matter and nutrients.

questions.question_text: Which irrigation method is the most efficient in terms of water use?
questions.explanation_correct: Drip irrigation is the most water-efficient method. Water is delivered directly to the roots of plants through a network of tubes with small drippers. This minimizes water wastage through evaporation and runoff, making it ideal for water-scarce areas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flood irrigation wastes the most water. Furrow irrigation is moderately efficient. Canal irrigation depends on water availability. Drip irrigation delivers water precisely to plant roots, making it the most efficient.

questions.question_text: Cross-breeding of local cattle breeds with exotic breeds is done to obtain:

options.text: Animals with higher milk yield and disease resistance

questions.explanation_correct: Cross-breeding local breeds (which have disease resistance and adaptability to local conditions) with exotic breeds (which have high milk yield) produces offspring combining both advantages — high milk production along with resistance to local diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The goal is not just appearance or reduced food consumption. Cattle cross-breeding is specifically done to combine high yield from exotic breeds with disease resistance from local breeds.

questions.question_text: Which bee species is commonly used in commercial bee keeping in India due to its high honey yield?
questions.explanation_correct: Apis mellifera (Italian bee) is commonly used in commercial bee keeping because it has a high honey yield, stays in the hive for long periods, breeds well, and has a gentle temperament. It produces more honey than the Indian bee (Apis cerana indica).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apis dorsata (rock bee) is wild and cannot be easily domesticated. Apis florea produces very little honey. While Apis cerana indica is also used, Apis mellifera is preferred commercially for its higher yield.

questions.question_text: Why is crop rotation with leguminous plants beneficial?

options.text: Legumes grow faster than other crops
Leguminous plants fix atmospheric nitrogen, enriching the soil

questions.explanation_correct: Crop rotation with leguminous plants (like gram, peas, lentils) is beneficial because legumes have Rhizobium bacteria in their root nodules that fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil. This enriches the soil with nitrogen, reducing the need for chemical fertilizers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Legumes do not necessarily grow faster. They need water like other crops. They do not prevent all pests. The key benefit is nitrogen fixation that enriches soil fertility.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a biotic factor that causes loss during grain storage?
questions.explanation_correct: Insects and rodents are biotic (living) factors that cause grain losses during storage. Insects eat and contaminate grains, while rodents consume and damage stored food. Biotic factors also include fungi, mites, and bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature, humidity, and moisture content are abiotic (non-living) factors. Insects and rodents are biotic factors that actively consume and damage stored grains.

questions.question_text: Integrated pest management (IPM) involves:

options.text: Using a combination of biological, cultural, and chemical methods to control pests

questions.explanation_correct: Integrated pest management (IPM) uses a combination of methods — biological control (using natural predators), cultural practices (crop rotation, timely sowing), and limited chemical use — to manage pests in an environmentally sustainable way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: IPM is not about using only chemicals or only organic methods, and definitely not about ignoring pests. It integrates multiple approaches for effective and sustainable pest management.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases commonly affects cattle?
questions.explanation_correct: Foot and mouth disease is a common viral disease that affects cattle, causing blisters on the mouth and feet. Other cattle diseases include anthrax, rinderpest, and mastitis. Regular vaccination and proper hygiene help prevent these diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria, dengue, and cholera are human diseases. Foot and mouth disease is specifically a livestock disease that affects cattle and other cloven-hoofed animals.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Mixed cropping reduces the risk of total crop failure.
Reason: In mixed cropping, if one crop fails, the other crop still provides yield.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Mixed cropping reduces total crop failure risk because two or more crops are grown together. If one crop fails due to disease or weather, the other crop(s) can still provide yield, ensuring some harvest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are true. Mixed cropping does reduce risk, and the reason that one crop surviving compensates for the other's failure is the correct explanation.

questions.question_text: In composite fish culture, a combination of fish species is used because:

options.text: Different species feed at different levels, maximizing food utilization in the pond
It is easier to catch them

questions.explanation_correct: In composite fish culture, species that feed at different levels of the pond are chosen together — surface feeders (catla), middle-zone feeders (rohu), bottom feeders (mrigal and common carp). This maximizes utilization of food available at all levels without competition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is not about appearance, ease of catching, or taste. It is about ecological efficiency — using species with different feeding habits to make the best use of all available food in the pond.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a preventive measure for protecting stored grains?

options.text: Drying grains to proper moisture levels before storage
Storing grains in open fields exposed to rain

questions.explanation_correct: Storing grains in open fields exposed to rain would lead to moisture damage, fungal growth, and insect infestation — the opposite of proper storage. Correct measures include drying grains, fumigation, using airtight containers, and maintaining proper temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drying, fumigation, and airtight containers are all proper storage methods. Exposing grains to rain is harmful and would cause rapid deterioration of stored grains.

questions.question_text: Excessive use of chemical fertilizers can lead to:
questions.explanation_correct: Excessive use of chemical fertilizers can degrade soil structure (reducing organic matter and killing beneficial microbes), cause water pollution (fertilizer runoff leads to eutrophication), and make soil acidic or alkaline, harming long-term productivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical fertilizers do not improve soil structure or increase humus — that is the function of organic manures. Excessive fertilizer use actually harms soil microorganisms and leads to environmental pollution.

questions.question_text: Wheat and gram are examples of kharif crops grown during the rainy season.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Wheat and gram are rabi crops, not kharif crops. They are sown in winter (October-November) and harvested in spring (March-April). Kharif crops (grown in the rainy season) include paddy, maize, and soybean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Wheat and gram are rabi (winter) crops, not kharif (rainy season) crops.

questions.question_text: Fertilizers are organic substances prepared from decomposed plant and animal matter.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Fertilizers are not organic — they are commercially manufactured chemical compounds that supply specific nutrients (mainly NPK). Manures are the organic substances prepared from decomposed plant and animal matter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. It describes manures, not fertilizers. Fertilizers are chemical, while manures are organic.

questions.question_text: Broilers are poultry birds raised for egg production.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Broilers are poultry birds raised for meat production, not egg production. Birds raised for egg production are called layers. Broilers are fed protein-rich and fat-rich food for rapid growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Broilers are raised for meat. Layers are raised for eggs.

questions.question_text: In composite fish culture, only one species of fish is grown in a pond to avoid competition.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Composite fish culture involves growing five or six different species in a single pond. Different species feed at different levels (surface, middle, bottom), so there is no competition. This actually maximizes food utilization in the pond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Composite culture means multiple species together. Growing one species is monoculture. The key advantage of composite culture is that different species occupy different ecological niches.

questions.question_text: Weeds compete with crops for water, nutrients, space, and light, thereby reducing crop yield.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Weeds are unwanted plants that grow alongside crops and compete for essential resources — water, soil nutrients, space, and sunlight. This competition reduces the availability of these resources for crops, thereby reducing their yield.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Weeds are a major agricultural problem because they compete with crops for all essential resources.

questions.question_text: Manures improve soil structure and increase water-holding capacity, while fertilizers provide specific nutrients quickly.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Manures are organic, improve soil texture, increase water retention, and add humus. Fertilizers are chemical substances that provide specific nutrients (N, P, K) quickly but do not improve soil structure. Both are needed for good crop production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. It correctly describes the key differences between manures (organic, improving soil structure) and fertilizers (chemical, providing specific nutrients quickly).

questions.question_text: Crops grown during the winter season from October to March are called ___ crops.
questions.explanation_correct: Rabi crops are sown in the winter season (October-November) and harvested in spring (March-April). Examples include wheat, gram, peas, mustard, and linseed. They require cool temperatures for growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'rabi'. Kharif crops grow in the rainy season. Rabi crops specifically grow in the winter season.

questions.question_text: Compost prepared using earthworms to decompose organic waste is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Vermicompost is made by using earthworms (vermi = worm) to break down organic waste into rich, nutrient-dense compost. The earthworm castings (excreta) form an excellent organic manure that improves soil fertility and structure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vermicompost'. It combines 'vermi' (worm) and 'compost'. Regular compost is made without worms; vermicompost specifically uses earthworms.

questions.question_text: Cattle used mainly for milk production are called ___ animals.
questions.explanation_correct: Milch animals are cattle breeds primarily raised for milk production. Examples of good milch breeds include Sahiwal, Gir, Red Sindhi (Indian breeds) and Jersey, Holstein-Friesian (exotic breeds). Draught animals are used for farm labour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'milch'. Draught animals are used for labour. Milch animals are specifically those kept for their milk-producing capability.

questions.question_text: The practice of keeping bees for honey production is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Apiculture is the scientific practice of keeping and managing bees for the production of honey, beeswax, and other bee products. It also helps in the pollination of crops. Apis mellifera is the most commonly used species in commercial apiculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'apiculture'. 'Api' comes from the Latin 'apis' meaning bee. Other similar terms include sericulture (silk), pisciculture (fish), and horticulture (gardens).

questions.question_text: The crossing of genetically different plants to produce offspring with desired traits is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Hybridisation is the process of crossing two genetically different plants (or varieties, species, or genera) to combine their desirable characteristics in the offspring. This is a key method in crop variety improvement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'hybridisation'. It is one of the main approaches to crop improvement, along with introduction of foreign varieties and genetic modification.

questions.question_text: Chemical substances used to kill or control weeds in crop fields are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Herbicides are chemical substances specifically designed to kill or inhibit the growth of weeds in crop fields. Examples include 2,4-D and atrazine. They target weeds without significantly harming the crop plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'herbicides'. Pesticides is a broader term. Insecticides kill insects, fungicides kill fungi, but herbicides specifically target weeds (herbs = plants).

questions.question_text: Which of the following nutrients is important for the growth of broiler chickens?

options.text: High protein diet with adequate fat and vitamins

questions.explanation_correct: Broiler chickens require a diet rich in protein and fat for rapid weight gain and muscle development, along with adequate vitamins (especially A and K). Their feed formulation is different from layers, which need more calcium for egg shell formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Low protein diet would not support the rapid growth needed for meat production. Just water or grain alone would be nutritionally inadequate. Broilers specifically need high protein with balanced fat and vitamin content.

questions.question_text: Marine fishery includes fish caught from:
questions.explanation_correct: Marine fishery involves catching fish from seas and oceans. Popular marine fish include pomfret, mackerel, tuna, sardines, and Bombay duck. Marine fishing uses trawlers, fishing nets, and other equipment to harvest fish from coastal and deep-sea waters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ponds, lakes, rivers, and canals are inland water sources (inland fishery). Aquariums are for ornamental purposes. Marine fishery specifically refers to fish from seas and oceans.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of intercropping over mixed cropping?

options.text: Seeds are mixed and sown randomly
Crops are grown in separate rows, making harvesting and management easier

questions.explanation_correct: In intercropping, crops are grown in separate rows in a definite pattern. This makes it easier to harvest each crop individually, apply specific treatments, and manage each crop separately. In mixed cropping, seeds are mixed, making individual management difficult.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Random sowing describes mixed cropping, not intercropping. Intercropping involves two or more crops, not one. Fertilizers may still be needed. The key advantage is the organized row arrangement.

questions.question_text: Honey bees are important for agriculture not only for honey but also because they:
questions.explanation_correct: Besides producing honey and beeswax, honey bees play a crucial role in the pollination of many crop plants. As they move from flower to flower collecting nectar, they transfer pollen, enabling fertilization and fruit/seed formation, which increases crop yield.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bees do not eat harmful insects (that would be biological pest control by predators). They do not produce fertilizer or control weeds. Their major agricultural benefit beyond honey is pollination.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an abiotic factor that can cause loss of stored grains?
questions.explanation_correct: Inappropriate moisture and temperature are abiotic (non-living) factors that cause grain losses during storage. High moisture promotes fungal growth, while extreme temperatures can degrade grain quality. Insects, rodents, and bacteria are biotic (living) factors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insects, rodents, and bacteria are biotic (living) factors. Moisture and temperature are abiotic (non-living) factors. Controlling abiotic conditions is essential for proper grain storage.
